name: Brush-tailed Bettong
description: It has an overall grayish coloration, relatively slender limbs, and a long, prehensile tail.
proportions: Body length 30–38 cm; tail length 29–36 cm; weight 1.2–1.6 kg
reproduction: Females are pregnant for 21 days and bear 1 young, which spends 90–110 days in the pouch
attractions: It is classified in a distinct group of so-called rat-kangaroos, differing from true kangaroos in several ways: they are smaller, have differently arranged teeth, a more varied diet, and a more mobile tail. The brush-tailed bettong spends the day hidden in forest undergrowth, building a spherical nest for rest, carrying materials in its curled tail.
breeding: We have kept bettongs since 2001 and have bred them repeatedly since 2004.
